gcci.text: At a realized H100 price near $3.22/hr—roughly half of U.S. spot rates—hardware supply is now adequate in some regions, but persistent export controls keep new capacity approvals and premium-tier chips structurally tight, implying capex allocation will favor older-generation inventory and bespoke accelerators rather than high-end GPUs.

gtpi.text: With input pricing compressing to roughly $1.56 per million tokens, the token market is entering a sustained price war; providers are racing to differentiate on latency, reliability, and specialized fine‑tunes rather than headline cost, while efficiency‑driven model innovations compress margins.

gagl.text: A 120 TWh annual load translates to roughly 10.3 GW of continuous power, already testing grid strain; without faster interconnection queues and behind‑the‑meter nuclear adoption, data‑center growth risks being carbon‑intensive and capacity‑constrained.

aipi.text: Infrastructure costs are stabilizing (H100), input pricing is in a deflationary spiral (tokens), and power needs are rising, suggesting a maturing market where growth remains strong but risk migrates to execution—grid access, interconnect timelines, and regulatory bottlenecks.
